conclusion: The problem involves predicting which container (D or E) liquid will flow into after being released from points A, B, and C and passing through baffles.
The setup includes a board with colored bars/baffles, three starting points (A, B, C) for liquid, and two containers (D, E) at the bottom.
The liquid flows downward and follows the paths created by the colored bars/channels.
Point A is marked with an orange marker at the top of the board.
The second image shows orange liquid flowing downward from point A.
The final image shows orange liquid following a path down and to the left.
The orange liquid from point A flows downward, follows obstacles, and ultimately reaches container D.
Point B is marked with an orange marker at the top of the board.
The second image shows orange liquid from point B merging with the flow from point A.
The final image confirms the orange liquid from point B follows the same path as liquid from point A.
The orange liquid from point B flows downward, merges with liquid from point A, and both streams follow the same path to container D.
Point C is marked with a teal/mint marker at the top of the board.
The second image shows teal liquid flowing downward from point C.
The final image shows teal liquid primarily flowing toward the middle.
The teal liquid from point C flows downward, branches somewhat, but the main flow goes toward container D and meets with the orange liquid.
All three liquids (from points A, B, and C) appear to eventually flow into container D.
The liquid streams merge at various points and create a branching pattern that ultimately leads to container D.
There does not appear to be significant flow into container E.
The liquid flowing from points A, B, and C will all flow into container D after passing through the baffles.
